title: Momentum - Change in velocity inelastic collision

content.description: At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, a slow-moving cart of mass <math alttext="m sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is traveling to the right at speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> a student drops a box of mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> onto the cart. The box does not bounce but slides backwards relative to the cart. At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> the cart and box travel together at speed <math alttext="v sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math> without slipping.
content.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the change in momentum of the cart between times <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The momentum of the cart decreases because the momentum of the cart is always conserved.
The momentum of the cart decreases because there is a net external force on the cart.
The momentum of the cart remains the same because momentum is always conserved.
The momentum of the cart remains the same because the box only had vertical momentum originally.

content.answer: The momentum of the cart decreases because there is a net external force on the cart.
